text.p: Biogen, Inc on Tuesday announced a two-for-one stock split effective November 15 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Nov. 4.

Wall Street analysts who follow the biotech company, which has had a solid runup since the U.S. Federal Drug Administration approved of its multiple sclerosis drug, Avonex, in May said the split would increase liquidity and give the Cambridge-based company more options to acquire licensing agreements.

Jim Vincent, Biogen's chairman and chief executive officer said, "The stock split is in keeping with the company's long-term strategy of broadening our stockholder base and increasing the liquidity of the company's shares."

David Stone of Cowen & Co said, "It won't mean much to institutional holders, but it will mean something to the individual holders and will make the shares easier to trade. It shouldn't affect the fundamentals."
Biogen said institutional investors make up 65 percent of its shareholders.

Bear Stearns David Molowa said he was not surprised at the split. "It seems very normal in this industry when stocks get up in the 80s and 90s that they split. They're trying to keep their investor audience."
In late afternoon trading, Biogen was hovering at 80-1/4, down 1/4 from the Monday close.
Asked if he thought the split would result in possible acquisitions by Biogen, Molowa replied, "Well, that's part of liquidity, isn't it."
